Before we try to answer the question "What is dark matter?" we should first examine why we think it exists. Precise astronomical observations strongly suggest the presence of "Non-Newtonian" motion of large celestial objects. This is based on the assumption that gravitation is the dominant 'action at a distance' force on a cosmological scale. If it is assumed that the mass of a galaxy can be determined by observing optically detectable objects and gasses then the total mass as well as the mass distribution in the structure should be determinable. The problem arises when an attempt is made to reconcile the observed mass and its distribution with the observed distribution of angular, or orbital, velocities of objects with the galaxy. This analysis strongly suggests that the mass model thus derived may be in error by as much as an order of magnitude. Other than consistent observational error (which is unlikely) there are two possibilities that come to mind; the presence of unobservable mass or Einstein-Newtonian dynamics is incomplete. All baryonic matter has mass and it also has detectable optical properties. So far, no optical or radiometric observation method has detected dark matter. However, the gravitational behavior is observable. These observations depend mostly on measurement of spectral shift due to velocity differences between the inertial frame of the observer and the thing being observed. If our understanding of the velocity related red-shift mechanism is correct then the presence of unobserved mass is directly confirmed by these observations. Recent observations of previously undetected massive gas clouds surrounding most, if not all, galaxies have complicated this analysis. It is estimated that these clouds may be significantly more massive than the galaxies embedded within them. This newly found mass suggests that a revision of galactic mass models is in order. This revision may result in a new set of requirements for the properties and quantity of dark matter in the universe… The issue of dark matter is really a two part question; 1) does it exist? and 2) what is it? Astronomical observations clearly indicate the presence of mass that has not been observed using conventional astronomical techniques and instruments. Anomalous non Newtonian motion in galaxies and clusters of galaxies is directly measurable by means of redshift observations. So unless you disregard the redshift velocity model (which some do) the presence of unobserved mass is inescapable if Newtonian dynamics is to remain intact. However, the assignment of non Newtonian motion is based on several assumptions. Historically it has been assumed that a relationship exists between the mass of a galaxy and its intrinsic luminosity. and that the distribution of mass is related to the distribution of luminous objects and gasses. Now there is evidence that this view is naive at best. Black holes, for example, are not luminous in and of themselves. Furthermore, the luminosity associated with these objects is as much a function of the quantity of material being drawn into them as it is a function of the objects mass. As a result, the black hole population of a galaxy must be taken into account when computing the total mass of the galaxy its self. Also, recent discoveries of massive gas clouds surrounding galaxies alters the mass model even further. However, while these phenomena require a restructure of galactic mass models there is still a significant quantity of implied mass that cannot be identified. It has been suggested that this residual mass consists of exotic or non-baryonic matter. So the question remains is dark matter simply ordinary matter that we cannot see for some reason or is it some form of exotic material that lies outside our concepts of atomic substances. It is beginning to look like it is a combination of both. Exotic dark matter will probably invoke new physics to accommodate its existence. And that is a very exciting proposition indeed.

What do you mean "question our perception"? If we observe something that is inconsistent with our theories, would you prefer us to modify our theories, or to say that our theories are right but our senses are wrong? The first is the scientific approach. The latter is insanity. We observe Universe and try to come up with theories that explain as much as possible with as little assumptions as possible. At this point we have observations that we can repeat over and over again, and each time get the same unexplainable (with respect to what we know) result. It means that there is something fundamental that we do not know. We invented concepts of "dark energy" and "dark matter" because they are the simplest explanations that we were able to come up with. It does not mean that they are right. Maybe correct explanations are more complicated. But so far we know so little that even if someone could invent them, we would be unable to tell if they are really the right ones.
